25 interesting facts about cars that you certainly did not know!

The love that many men feel about cars inherited from their fathers and their friends, in their youth. The first gifts and toys of young boys are always small cars, so it's no wonder that in time they turn into sincere enthusiasts in the auto-moto industry and competitions related to this lifestyle. But there are some facts that even the most ambitious industry connoisseurs do not know. Some will surprise you, some will smile, and some of you will also get a new perspective on this crazy world we live in. Certainly, an interesting story for coffee debate. Enjoy!

  • The first semaphore in the world was set up in the United States in Cleveland back in 1914 at the corner of Euclid Avenue and East 105. The installation of traffic lights helped control chaos on US streets from cars, pedestrians, bicycles, horses and trams.


  • The first traffic accident in the world was recorded in 1769. The car is still preserved in a broken state.


  • In 1896, the first death occurred as a result of a car accident.


  • In China, for 40 euros, your car will bring someone to your house through all the city crowds, and will take you to your destination by bike.


  • The car is the most recycled product in the world.


  • The most expensive car ever produced was the Buggati Royal Kellner Coupe. Price? Only $ 8.7 million


  • Rolls Royce's famous ghost statue is nicknamed Spirit of Ectasy, or Spirit of Ecstasy. Yeah, he's dealing with drugs.


  • Only 18% of the engine generated by the gasoline ends in power on the wheels.


  • The oldest car that has been preserved to date has been produced in France in 1884. It has recently sold for $ 4.6 million at auction.


  • The record time it takes to change the complete car engine is 42 seconds. The record was set to Forda Escort in 1985.


  • Approximately 1 billion vehicles are active on the planet.


  • The car dashboard was in its original form a wooden board that protected the driver from the mud that horses were thrown while driving.


  • In France, alcotest is part of the obligatory equipment in every car.


  • The lowest legal car in the world high is only 48 centimeters. It's called Flatmobile.


  • While was in prison, Hitler sought a loan for Mercedes.


  • The most popular Volkswagen cars Passat, Polo and Jetta are named like the names of winds.


  • 80% of cars in Albania are Mercedes.


  • In South Africa, BMW cars mount flame launchers for frequent attempts to steal.


  • People older than 75 in Japan need to have a special label on the back of the car.


  • Ferrari produces 14 cars each day.


  • Toyota produces 13,000 vehicles per day.


  • Every fourth car on the planet is produced in China.


  • Formula 1 can ride at the speed of 193 km / h by the tunnel ceiling. So much downforce produces its aerodynamics!


  • If the remote control key car is pressed 256 times, and if your car is not near, the key will stop working.


  • Formulas 1 use the same exhaust pipes as nuclear reactors.
